abstract: The Olympus board’s decision to fire Michael C. Woodford after only two weeks shows that change was sorely needed.
snippet: The Olympus board’s decision to fire Michael C. Woodford after only two weeks shows that change was sorely needed.
lead_paragraph: Olympus’s embarrassing decision to dump its British chief executive two weeks after naming him to the job shows that reform in Japan is a slow and fitful process. The executive, Michael C. Woodford, was brought in to clean house at the company, and became one of Japan’s handful of foreign corporate bosses. That the board decided to fire him so soon shows the medicine was distasteful. It also strengthens the case for a bigger dose.

headline.main: Olympus Chief Goes, but Push for Reform Goes On

byline.original: By Wayne Arnold and John Foley
